Present/permanent address: NO. 2, Sipailou, China. NO. 2, Sipailou China The effective utilization of biomass is essential for addressing environmental challenges. The direct conversion of cellulose into chemicals and fuels is a key step in fostering a sustainable society. In this study, a mesoporous Pt-WOx/Nb2O5 catalyst is synthesized and characterized using N2 sorption, XRD, ICP, CO pulse, TEM, SEM, NH3-TPD, PY-IR, H2-TPR, and XPS. Under optimized catalyst preparation and reaction conditions, the yields of ethanol and propanol reach 50.3 % and 20.2 %, respectively. The mesoporous structure of Nb2O5, coupled with Pt, provides a rich balance of acidic and hydrogenation-active sites. Additionally, WOx plays a crucial role in the CC bond cleavage of cellulosic glucose and the CO bond cleavage of ethylene glycol, facilitating ethanol formation through Pt and the abundant Lewis acid sites from Nb2O5. Graphical Abstract Keywords Biomass Cellulosic ethanol Propanol Pt-WOx/Nb2O5 Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The depletion of fossil fuel reserves and escalating environmental concerns have intensified the search for sustainable alternatives to traditional energy and chemical sources. Among renewable resources, cellulose, the most abundant component of biomass, holds immense potential as a sustainable substitute for fossil fuels in producing chemicals and energy [1]. However, conventional acid-catalyzed depolymerization methods for cellulose face significant drawbacks, including harsh reaction conditions and environmental concerns [2]. To address these challenges, chemocatalytic approaches utilizing multifunctional catalysts have emerged, enabling efficient one-pot conversions of cellulose into valuable products [3]. Cellulosic ethanol stands out as a key platform chemical derived from biomass, with direct applications as a biofuel in gasoline [4]. Ethanol production can proceed through two primary pathways. The first involves the one-pot transformation of cellulose through intermediates such as glucose and glycolaldehyde, ultimately yielding ethanol. The second approach converts cellulose into methyl glycolate in the presence of oxygen and methanol, followed by its hydrogenation to produce ethanol in a two-step process [5,6]. Zhang et al. first reported the catalytic conversion of cellulose to lower diols in 2008 [6], demonstrating the efficacy of W-based catalysts, particularly nickel-promoted tungsten carbide, in achieving a 61 % yield of ethylene glycol. Subsequent studies have advanced this field, focusing on the development of novel catalysts to optimize diol yields. For instance, Wang et al. [7] employed an H2WO4-Pt/ZrO2 catalyst for direct cellulose conversion, achieving a 32 % ethanol yield. They found that H2WO4 facilitates the cleavage of CC bonds in the glucose, whereas Pt/ZrO2 containing appropriate ratios of Pt0 and Pt2+ promoted the formation of ethanol through selective C-O bond activation. Similarly, Zhang et al. [8] developed a multifunctional Mo/Pt/WOx catalyst, achieving a one-pot ethanol yield of 43.2 C-mol% through tandem reactions. Other notable advancements include graphene-encapsulated nickel catalysts reported by Ma et al., yielding 69.1 % ethanol, [9] and a Ru-WOx/HZSM-5 catalyst by Fu et al., [10] achieving an 87.5 % ethanol yield from 1 wt% cellulose. In this study, we present a novel multifunctional catalyst, Pt-WOx/Nb2O5 (2 < x < 3), for the one-pot conversion of cellulose into ethanol and propanol. Notably, alongside ethanol production, the catalyst facilitated the formation of propanol, with a maximum yield of 20 %. Under optimized conditions of 508 K, 4 MPa H2, and a 4-h reaction time, cellulose was fully converted, yielding ethanol and propanol at 50.3 % and 20.2 %, respectively. Mechanistic insights revealed that Nb2O5 provided Brønsted acid sites for cellulose hydrolysis, WOx catalyzed retro-aldol reactions to cleave CC bonds in glucose, and Pt promoted the hydrogenation of glycolaldehyde to ethanol. 2 Experimental methods 2.1 Chemicals Cellulose (Macklin, 65 μm), Niobium pentachloride (NbCl5, 99.9 %), Ammonium tungstate (Meryer, 98.5 %), Ruthenium trichloride trihydrate (Macklin, 99.9 %), Chloroplatinic acid solution (8 wt%, Aladdin), Nickel nitrate hexahydrate (Aladdin, 98 %), MCM-41 (XFNANO), Ethanol (Meryer, 99.9 %), Glycolaldehyde dimer (HEOWNS), Ethylene glycol (Macklin, 99.9 %), Formic acid (Meryer, 99 %), Propanol (Meryer,99.5 %), Potassium humate (98 %), 1,2-Butanediol (Meryer,98 %), Methanol (Meryer, 99 %), Glycerol (Meryer, 99 %), 1,2-propanol. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Nb2O5 was prepared by sol-gel method according to the literature [11]. Firstly, 2.0 g Poly (ethylene oxide)-poly (propylene oxide)-poly (ethylene oxide) triblock copolymers (P123) was dissolved in 20 g of propanol with stirring at 40 ℃ for 1 h. Subsequently, 7.5 g NbCl5 was added into the above mixed solution and stirred vigorously for 6 h. Then 2 ml water was added into the precursor solution and stirred for 12 h to get the final precursor solution. After the aging for 8–10 days at room temperature, the precursor was calcined at temperatures range from 300 ℃ to 600 ℃, and the final Nb2O5 powder was obtained by agate mortar grinding. The Niobium-based catalysts were prepared by co-impregnation method. A typical Pt-WOx/Nb2O5 preparation procedure was as follows: 1 g Nb2O5, 45.6 μL chloroplatinic acid solution and 0.48 g ammonium tungstate were added into 10 ml water. The mixture was stirred for 24 h in 60 ℃. Subsequently, the precursor was transferred into an oven and dried at 120 ℃ for 12 h and then transferred into muffle furnace calcining to get clean catalyst. After drying and calcination, the catalyst was reduced in H2/Ar2 atmosphere at temperatures 400–500 ℃ for 4 h with a heating rate of 4 ℃min−1 before reaction. The WOx was prepared by sol-gel method as above. Catalysts for other carriers (molecular sieves, carbon, tungsten oxide) are prepared by the impregnation method described above. 2.3 Experimental The catalytic reaction for cellulose to ethanol and propanol was performed in a 25 ml high-pressure batch reactor. In a typical reaction, 0.08 g cellulose, 0.04 g catalyst and 8 ml 0.06 mol/L phosphoric acid solution (H3PO4-H2O) were put into the autoclave. Before the reaction, the residual air in the reactor is flushed with hydrogen, and finally the reactor is filled with hydrogen at a pressure of about 4 MPa. The reaction temperature is 190–250 ℃ and reaction time is 60–720 min. After reaction, the reactor was cooled to room temperature naturally and gas products were captured in a pre-purged gas cylinder and quantitatively analyzed by GC analysis. The liquid product was filtered through a 0.45 μm membrane and then analyzed by high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) with 0.05 mmol/L H2SO4-H2O as mobile phase and RI as the detector. A Shodex column was used with the mobile phase flow rate of 0.4 ml/min and column temperature of 328 K. 2.4 Catalyst characterization Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was utilized to obtain TEM images using a JEM-2100F microscope operating at 200kv. A scanning electron microscopy (SEM, SU70) was utilized by FEI Inspect F50, which was operated at 1.0 kV. The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the catalysts were examined by Bruker Endeavour D8 Discovery diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation with the scanning speed of 10° min−1 from 5° to 80°. Nitrogen physisorption was conducted on a Autosorb-iQ analyzer (Quantachrome Co. Ltd) at − 196 ℃ after 0.1 g samples were pretreated at 200 ℃ for 12 h under vacuum conditions. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller（BET）and Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method were utilized to calculate the specific surface area and pore size distribution respectively. Elemental analysis was performed on Agilent ICP-OES 5110 equipped with a free-running generator operating at 1200 W. The catalyst is mixed with nitric and hydrofluoric acids for 12 h at 110 °C. The cooled liquid is mixed with ammonia and heated to 100 °C for 2 h. Hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was performed using Micromeritics Autochem Ⅱ 2920. The H2 consumption during sample reduction was monitored via TCD and mass spectrometry. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were carried out using a Thermo Fisher Scientific Nexsa 250Xi photoelectron spectrometer, which is equipped with an aluminum anode (Al Kα = 1846.6 eV). Furthermore, all binding energies were calibrated against the C1s peak, which is set at 284.8 eV. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Catalyst screening To identify effective catalysts for the hydrolysis of cellulose to ethanol and propanol, we initially screened a series of tungsten-based (W-based) bimetallic catalysts incorporating nickel (Ni), platinum (Pt), or ruthenium (Ru) as active metals. Tungsten was selected for its proven ability to cleave secondary CO bonds in glycerol to produce 1,3-propanediol [12] and its critical role in cellulose CC bond cleavage to form glycolaldehyde, an ethylene glycol precursor [5,13]. Catalysts were prepared using various supports, including biochar, molecular sieves, tungsten oxide, and niobium oxide (Nb2O5). Nickel-tungsten catalysts demonstrated moderate ethanol production, with ethanol yields ranging from 10 % to 30 % across different supports (entries 1, 4, 7, and 10, Table 1). Among these, Nb2O5-supported nickel-tungsten catalysts achieved the highest ethanol yield of 33.2 %. However, other supports, such as biochar, molecular sieves, and tungsten oxide, yielded ethanol below 30 %. Similarly, ruthenium-tungsten catalysts exhibited low ethanol yields, with a maximum of 25.9 % achieved using Nb2O5 as the support (entries 3, 6, 9, and 12, Table 1). Despite this, ruthenium-based catalysts demonstrated superior selectivity for ethylene glycol, achieving a maximum yield of 52.6 % with Nb2O5. In contrast, platinum-tungsten catalysts displayed remarkable performance in ethanol production. Across various supports, ethanol yields were consistently within the range of 20–50 %. The Nb2O5-supported platinum-tungsten catalyst achieved the highest ethanol yield of 50.3 %, accompanied by the highest propanol yield of 20.2 % and a carbon molar yield of 76.9 %. Based on these screening results, platinum and tungsten were confirmed as the most effective active metals, with Nb2O5 as the optimal support. Subsequently, we focused on optimizing the catalyst preparation method and reaction conditions to further enhance ethanol yield. 3.2 Catalyst optimization The performance of niobium oxide (Nb2O5) as a catalyst support can be influenced by its pore structure, specific surface area, crystal phase, and acidity. These characteristics were optimized by varying the preparation process, including the use of different surfactants and calcination temperatures. 3.2.1 Effect of surfactants on niobium oxide Four surfactants—Poly (ethylene oxide)-poly (propylene oxide)-poly (ethylene oxide) triblock copolymer (P123), polyethylene-polypropylene glycol (F127), hexadecyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB), and fatty alcohol polyoxyethylene ether (AEO)—were utilized in a sol-gel synthesis of Nb2O5. The preparation method followed established protocols, with all samples calcined at 500 °C. The specific surface area and pore characteristics of Nb2O5 prepared using different surfactants are summarized in Table S1. The results showed that metal loading decreased the BET surface area and pore volume of Nb2O5 due to the impregnation of tungsten oxide and platinum, which likely covered the Nb2O5 surface and blocked its pores. Among the four surfactants, Nb2O5 prepared with P123 achieved an optimal balance of specific surface area, pore volume, and pore size. This structure facilitated glucose, derived from cellulose hydrolysis, entering the mesoporous catalyst pores and interacting with active metal sites, enhancing ethanol yield. In contrast, catalysts prepared with F127 had smaller surface areas but larger pore volumes, while those prepared with CTAB and AEO exhibited increased surface areas but reduced pore volumes and sizes, leading to lower ethanol yields. N2-sorption isotherms (Fig. S1) confirmed the mesoporous structure of all samples [14]. TEM images (Fig. S2a, S2b) revealed a porous structure in Nb2O5 and Pt-WOx/Nb2O5, attributed to surfactant removal during calcination. High-resolution TEM (Fig. S2d) showed a fringe spacing of 0.228 nm, corresponding to the (111) facet of Pt [15]. Elemental mapping via EDX indicated uniform dispersion of Pt, W, and Nb, with Pt dispersion measured at 43 % (Table S2). ICP-OES analysis further quantified platinum and tungsten contents at 1.17 % and 20.16 %, respectively. Catalyst evaluation ( Fig. 1) revealed that Nb2O5 prepared with P123 and CTAB produced the highest ethanol yields of 50.3 % and 34.9 %, respectively. Propanol yields for all catalysts ranged between 15–20 %, resulting in total monohydric alcohol yields of up to 70.5 %. Consequently, P123 was identified as the optimal surfactant for preparing Nb2O5-based catalysts. All subsequent discussions are based on Nb2O5 prepared using P123 as the surfactant. 3.2.2 Niobium oxide obtained at different calcination temperatures To optimize the crystallinity and acidity of Nb₂O₅ catalysts, calcination was performed at temperatures between 300 °C and 600 °C. XRD, NH₃-TPD, and PY-IR analyses revealed distinct structural transformations. At 300 °C, Nb₂O₅ remained amorphous, while calcination at 400–600 °C induced a transition to a pseudo-hexagonal TT-phase structure (PDF#28-0317) [16]. Lower temperatures consistently produced amorphous forms, whereas calcination in the range of 400–600 °C yielded either TT-phase, orthogonal T-phase, or a combination, depending on preparation conditions. The TT-phase is known to transform into the T-phase at temperatures above 700 °C [17]. Catalytic testing showed that Nb₂O₅ calcined between 500 °C and 600 °C exhibited the highest activity, likely due to the presence of the TT-phase or its mixture with the T-phase, which effectively facilitated cellulose hydrogenation to ethanol and propanol. After reduction, Pt-WOx/Nb₂O5 catalysts prepared at these temperatures exhibited WO₃ crystallinity according to PDF#33-1387 [18]. XPS analysis showed the presence of partial W5+ in WOx, and thus the partial reduction of WOx to W20O58 was assumed at a reduction temperature of 400–500 °C, which is similar to the study by Ghoreishi et al. [19]. They categorized the reduction of WO3 into three parts: WO3 →W20O58 (540 ℃) →WO2 (775 ℃) →W (higher temperature). Notably, no distinct Pt peaks were observed in the XRD patterns, indicating highly dispersed Pt species, likely due to the low loading (1.17 wt%). Notably, no distinct Pt peaks were observed in the XRD patterns, indicating highly dispersed Pt species, likely due to the low loading (1.17 wt%). The acidity of the catalysts, evaluated using NH₃-TPD and PY-IR, revealed that Nb2O5 calcined at 400 °C exhibited the highest acid density. With the addition of Pt and WOx, the overall acidity increased. The acid density peaked for Pt-WOx/Nb2O5 calcined at 500 °C (15.04 μmol NH3·m−2), whereas calcination at 400 °C and 600 °C resulted in significantly higher (33.02 μmol NH3·m−2) and lower (5.21 μmol NH3·m−2) values, respectively. Moderate acidity at 500 °C was most effective, achieving 70.4 % total monoalcohol yield, compared to 44.4 % at 400 °C, likely due to differences in crystalline structure. NH3-TPD results showed weak (170–180 °C), medium-strong (520–530 °C), and strong (720 °C) acid desorption peaks for Nb2O5. After loading Pt and WOx, the strong acid peaks disappeared for catalysts calcined at 500 °C and 600 °C, leaving only weak and medium-strong peaks. This change suggests that moderate acidity at 500 °C contributed to optimal catalytic performance. The production of ethanol from cellulose involves hydrolysis, glucose retro-aldolization, and glycolaldehyde hydrogenation. Brønsted acids promote hydrolysis, while Lewis acids facilitate retro-aldol reactions [20]. As shown in Table 3, Nb₂O₅ calcined at 500 °C had the highest Lewis acid content and a moderate Lewis-to-Brønsted acid ratio, enabling efficient glucose conversion [21]. Fig. 4 further confirmed the distinct acid characteristics at 500 °C, correlating with the catalyst's superior performance. Catalytic evaluations (Fig. 1) demonstrated that Nb₂O₅ calcined at 500 °C delivered the highest yields of ethanol (50.3 %) and propanol (20.2 %). In contrast, calcination at 300 °C resulted in significantly lower activity (8.3 % ethanol yield). The enhanced activity at 500 °C highlights the importance of calcination temperature in achieving optimal structural and acidic properties for cellulose hydrogenation. 3.3 Reductive properties and surface chemical state of Pt-WOx/Nb2O5 The reductive properties of Pt-WOx/Nb2O5 catalysts were investigated using H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR). Reference samples, including Pt/Nb2O5, Pt-WOx/Nb2O5, and WOx/Nb2O5, were analyzed to differentiate the reduction peaks of various phases. As shown in Fig. S3, reduction peaks at 170 °C and 196 °C correspond to the reduction of platinum species, while peaks at 718 °C and 722 °C are associated with the reduction of WO3 to WO3-x (0 < x < 1) [22]. Previous study [23] suggest that Nb2O5 reduction occurs above 800 °C, with a characteristic peak at 855 °C in the Pt/Nb2O5 sample. Notably, after Pt loading, the reduction peak of WO3 shifted from 718 °C to 734 °C. Similarly, introducing WO3 increased the reduction temperature of Nb2O5 from 855 °C to 870 °C. These observations indicate mutual influences between WO3 and Nb2O5 during the reduction process: WO3 reduction temperature became higher with Pt, and Nb2O5 reduction became slightly more challenging with WO3. The surface chemical state of the catalysts was characterized by XPS. The Pt 4f7/2 and Pt 4f5/2 peaks at 74.8 eV and 79.2 eV, respectively, confirm the presence of Pt primarily in the metallic Pt0 state, with some contribution from Pt2+ [24]. Analysis of the W 4f spectrum revealed overlapping signals between W 5p3/2 in the low chemical state and W 4f5/2 in the high chemical state. This overlap indicates that tungsten exists as a multivalent species, with W5+ and W6+ identified on the catalyst surface [25]. Peaks at 37.9 eV (W 4f5/2) and 35.8 eV (W 4f7/2) were attributed to W6+ in the WO3 phase, which dominated the catalyst surface [26]. Under H2/Ar2 reduction conditions, WO3 is partially reduced to WO3-x, with W5+ sites acting as Lewis base. These W5+ species are crucial active sites that facilitate the glucose retro-aldol condensation reaction, supporting their significant role in catalytic performance [27]. 3.4 Optimization of reaction time and reaction temperature Optimizing reaction time is critical for maximizing ethanol yield. Reaction durations ranging from 1 to 16 h were investigated. Ethanol yield was minimal after 1 h but increased significantly after 2 h, reaching a peak of 50.3 % at 6 h. Beyond this point, the yield stabilized. In contrast, propanol yield remained steady at 16–22 %, showing minimal sensitivity to reaction time. The yield of ethylene glycol, an intermediate, was consistently below 10 %. This lower yield likely reflects the high hydrogenation activity of Pt, which accelerates the conversion of ethylene glycol into ethanol. Reaction temperature is another essential parameter influencing the production of ethanol and propanol from cellulose. At temperatures of 190 °C or higher, small amounts of ethanol and propanol were produced, attributed to the energy-intensive nature of reactions such as cellulose hydrolysis, retro-aldol condensation, ethanol aldehyde hydrogenation, and ethylene glycol dehydrogenation. As the temperature increased, the yields of ethanol and propanol rose steadily, reaching 12.2 % and 16.6 %, respectively, at 210 °C. The highest yields—50.3 % for ethanol and 20.2 % for propanol—were obtained at 230 °C. However, temperatures exceeding 230 °C promoted side reactions, leading to the formation of oligosaccharides and humins during cellulose hydrolysis. This reduced the availability of intermediate products, such as ethanol aldehyde, and consequently lowered the yield of target products. 3.5 Stability and reusability of Pt-WOx/Nb2O5 catalyst The stability and reusability of a heterogeneous catalyst are of significance for its practical application. The product yield of four recycling tests is shown in Fig. S5. After the first cycle of testing, the ethanol yield decreased from 50.3 % to 43.6 %, however, it remained relatively stable over the next four cycles. We analyzed the catalysts by XRD and ICP (Fig. S6 and Table S3) and found that the active metals Pt and W were lost during the reaction, while the XRD plots remained almost unchanged. Combined with the catalytic effect of Pt as described in the article, we hypothesized that the decrease in the content of Pt might be unfavorable to the hydrogenolysis of ethylene glycol to ethanol, which in turn caused the decrease in the yield of ethanol. 3.6 Proposed reaction path In the ethanol production process from cellulose, the same catalyst and reaction conditions were used to explore potential intermediates. Both glucose and fructose were completely converted in the presence of Pt-WOx/Nb2O5. The main products from glucose were C2 alcohols, such as ethanol and ethylene glycol ( Table 4, entry 1), while fructose primarily yielded C3 alcohols, including 1,2-propanediol (1,2-PD) and propanol (Table 4, entry 2). When glycolaldehyde and ethylene glycol were used as substrates, ethanol selectivity reached 36.5 % and 26.8 %, respectively (entry 3 and 4), although ethylene glycol was not fully converted, which may explain the relatively low ethanol yield. Using DHA and DL as substrates produced 1,2-PD, glycerol, and propanol (entry 6 and 7), confirming that DHA and DL are formed from fructose via retro-aldol condensation. Glycerol also generated 1,2-PD and propanol under similar conditions (entry 8). When 1,2-PD was used as a substrate, it was converted to 45.5 % with the Pt-WOx/Nb2O5 catalyst, with propanol as the main product and lower yields of ethanol and ethylene glycol. In particular, we believe that H3PO4 plays an important role in the catalytic system. First, we speculate that H3PO4 promotes the hydrolysis of cellulose and facilitates the selective breaking of the CC bond of the glucose obtained by hydrolysis. Acidic promotion of cellulose hydrolysis is well recognized [13]. By changing the substrate, we found that there is a difference in alcohol yield when glucose and cellulose are used as substrates, as shown in Table S4 (entry 1 and entry 3). It is noteworthy that cellulose with a higher alcohol yield than glucose, more glucose is dehydrated to form oligomers in our catalytic system when glucose is substrate (entry 1). Therefore, we believe that H3PO4 accelerates the hydrolysis of cellulose to glucose while somehow slowing down the formation of oligomers from glucose obtained by cellulose hydrolysis, while facilitating the retro-aldol condensation reaction of glucose. The interaction between glucose and H3PO4 has been demonstrated by Liu et al. by NMR [9]. Secondly, we hypothesize that H3PO4 promotes the dehydration of ethylene glycol to form ethanol. By comparing the product distribution before and after the addition of H3PO4, we found that the ethanol yield was higher in the H3PO4 group, but the ethylene glycol yield was lower (entry 3 and 4). Meanwhile, Pt-WOx/Nb2O5 converts more EG to ethanol with the addition of H3PO4(entry 5 and 6). Therefore, we speculate that H3PO4 can catalyze the dehydration of ethylene glycol to form ethanol. Based on these findings and previous studies, a reaction pathway for the direct conversion of cellulose to ethanol over Pt-WOx/Nb2O5 is proposed ( Fig. 6). The process follows these steps: (1) Cellulose is first hydrolyzed to glucose by H+ from H3PO4; (2) Glucose is then converted to glycolaldehyde through CC bond cleavage by WOx; (3) Glycolaldehyde undergoes rapid hydrogenation to ethylene glycol (EG) by Pt-WOx/Nb2O5; and (4) EG is further converted to ethanol via hydrogenolysis. Another pathway for the production of propanol from cellulose is also shown in Fig. 6, where cellulose is hydrolyzed to glucose, glucose isomerizes to fructose, and fructose undergoes retro-aldol condensation to form C3 alcohol intermediates, which are subsequently hydrogenated to propanol. 4 Conclusion A series of Pt-WOx/Nb2O5 catalysts were synthesized using sol-gel and impregnation methods for the one-pot conversion of cellulose to ethanol. Under optimized catalyst preparation and reaction conditions (including surfactant choice, Nb2O5 calcination temperature, reaction temperature, and reaction time), the yields of ethanol and propanol reached 50.3 % and 20.2 %, respectively. The mesoporous structure of Nb2O5, combined with the introduction of Pt, contributed to an optimal balance of acidic and hydrogenation-active sites. Additionally, WOx played a crucial role in the CC bond cleavage of glucose from cellulose and the CO bond cleavage of ethylene glycol, facilitating ethanol formation via Pt and the abundant Lewis acid sites of Nb2O5. Future efforts to optimize this one-pot conversion process will focus on enhancing the selectivity for ethanol, ethylene glycol, and propanol through careful catalyst design. Achieving this goal will require a deeper understanding of the reaction mechanism at the molecular level. CRediT authorship contribution statement Zhang Xinghua: Writing – review & editing. coredata.dc:description: The effective utilization of biomass is essential for addressing environmental challenges. The direct conversion of cellulose into chemicals and fuels is a key step in fostering a sustainable society. In this study, a mesoporous Pt-WOx/Nb2O5 catalyst is synthesized and characterized using N2 sorption, XRD, ICP, CO pulse, TEM, SEM, NH3-TPD, PY-IR, H2-TPR, and XPS. Under optimized catalyst preparation and reaction conditions, the yields of ethanol and propanol reach 50.3 % and 20.2 %, respectively. The mesoporous structure of Nb2O5, coupled with Pt, provides a rich balance of acidic and hydrogenation-active sites. Additionally, WOx plays a crucial role in the CC bond cleavage of cellulosic glucose and the CO bond cleavage of ethylene glycol, facilitating ethanol formation through Pt and the abundant Lewis acid sites from Nb2O5.

coredata.dc:title: Enhanced conversion of cellulose to ethanol and propanol using a mesoporous Pt-WOx/Nb2O5 catalyst
